title: 114_s3292
content: The Act may be cited as the "Synthetics Trafficking and Overdose Prevention Act of 2016" or the "STOP Act of 2016." Improvements to United States mail security are included in the Act. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended regarding the Importer of Record, specifying who can file required documentation for merchandise entry. This includes the owner, purchaser, consignee, or a person with a valid license under section 641. The Postmaster General or designee can also file for non-letter class mail entries. The Importer of Record must be eligible to file required documentation for merchandise entry. U.S. Customs and Border Protection can accept a consignee's declaration of ownership without liability. Non-letter class mail refers to products provided by the USPS or Universal Postal Union under specific regulations. The Importer of Record must be eligible to file required documentation for merchandise entry. U.S. Customs and Border Protection can accept a consignee's declaration of ownership without liability. Non-letter class mail refers to products provided by the USPS or Universal Postal Union under specific regulations. Regulations related to informal customs entries require the Secretary of the Treasury to issue regulations within six months of the enactment of the Synthetics Trafficking and Overdose Prevention Act of 2016. The Postmaster General or designee, including those with a valid license under section 641, must file informal customs entries for non-letter class mail meeting specific requirements. The Postmaster General or designee, potentially with a valid license under section 641, is designated as the importer of record for non-letter class mail. The Postmaster General or designee, including those with a valid license under section 641, is designated as the importer of record for non-letter class mail subject to regulations. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue regulations within six months to implement this amendment. Customs fees for dutiable mail items prepared by a customs officer are set at $5, with exceptions for non-letter class mail. The amendment requires the Postmaster General to provide advanced electronic information for non-letter class mail to U.S. Customs and Border Protection. The effective date of this amendment is six months after the enactment of the Act. The Tariff Act of 1930 defines the importation of goods into the United States. The Secretary of the Treasury must issue regulations within six months to implement a section of the Trade Act of 2002. The Secretary of State is prohibited from entering into any international postal arrangement that conflicts with this Act or its amendments.
